title: Who Even Is An Entrepreneur?: Crash Course Business - Entrepreneurship #1
description:
CrashCourse
12.6M subscribers
SUBSCRIBE
You've probably heard the word "Entrepreneur" thrown around a lot in business. It conjures images of Elon Musk, Bill Gates, or Oprah Winfrey. But, it goes way beyond that. In this episode of Crash Course Business: Entrepreneurship, Anna helps us to figure out who Entrepreneurs are, and what that title actually means.


***

title: What is an entrepreneur?
description:
Business Wales/Busnes Cymru
19.2K subscribers
SUBSCRIBE
http://businesswales.gov.uk/bigideas/
The folk at Big Ideas Wales know that there's no one better to tell you what's an entrepreneur and the skills you'll need than: entrepreneurs. So they asked some, and here's what they had to say...

Attitude, creativity, organisation and relationships were the 4 key points that make a successful entrepreneur:

Having a positive attitude will get you a long way.

All you need is a bit of imagination and the ability to think a bit differently and BINGO, you’ve come up with a brilliant new idea.

To get to grips with the day to day running of things good organisation is essential.

Running a business is definitely a people thing. The more people you know the easier it will be to use your powers of persuasion and get things done.
http://business.wales.gov.uk/bigideas/

title: Do you have for it takes to be an entrepreneur? The 5 skills to get you there!
description:
Cuttles
46 subscribers
SUBSCRIBE
Have you ever asked yourself the question: What does it take to be an entrepreneur? We have! So in this video, we will show you five traits that every successful entrepreneur needs. You will learn why they are so important if you want your startup to succeed. 

Is 'quirky' part of the job description for entrepreneurs?
Have you ever heard those stories about successful entrepreneurs with all sorts of quirky habits that should explain why they have become the huge successes they are? Like wearing the same clothes every single day. Or breaking their days down into five-minute intervals. Or reading 50 books a year.

And have you ever thought that if that's what it takes to become an entrepreneur, you're probably better suited for a day job? No need to give up just yet. While quirky habits make good stories and probably work for Zuckerberg, Musk, and Gates, you can be a great entrepreneur and still change up your wardrobe every once in a while.

So do you have what it takes to become an entrepreneur?
The fact that you have thought to yourself, "I want to be an entrepreneur," is already a pretty clear sign. And there's not just one right recipe for what makes a good entrepreneur.

There are some skills, though, that will give you an advantage in the startup game. A good first step to take is to touch base with those skills.

Skill #1: You know how to act
- Partner up
- Write a solid business plan
- Prioritize your work and plan your days

Skill #2: You’re not afraid to fail, and you get back up - every time
- Accept that failure is inevitable
- Know how to get back up

Skill #3: You care about the problem
- Be curious
- Find out what pisses you off

Skill #4: You’re motivated - and keep going when you’re not
- Remember why you started
- Action builds motivation

Skill #5: You’re okay with uncertainty and willing to take risks
- Prepare for challenges and be ready to pivot
- Know the unknowns

If you want more information of the skills and steps, you can read our full course in our Startup Academy https://www.cuttles.io/startup-academ.... We'll walk you through the most important entrepreneurial skills and show you how to become a successful entrepreneur. And if they're not part of your DNA already, we will teach you how to work them up. You'll also get more details on the 12 tips you can use to work up those skills, even if they aren't really in your nature.
SHOW LESS

title: What Can You Learn from Your Competition?: Crash Course Business Entrepreneurship #4
description:
CrashCourse
12.6M subscribers
SUBSCRIBE
We’re used to competitions with clear winners and losers: baseball games, math olympiads, pie-eating contests, and games involving thrones. We crown a victor and everyone else goes home empty-handed! 

In business, though, there isn’t just one winner. So as entrepreneurs, we have to take stock in the middle of the competition, and ask the question: “how competitive am I?”


***

title: How I became an entrepreneur at 66 | Paul Tasner
description:
TED
19.9M subscribers
SUBSCRIBE
It's never too late to reinvent yourself. Take it from Paul Tasner -- after working continuously for other people for 40 years, he founded his own start-up at age 66, pairing his idea for a business with his experience and passion. And he's not alone. As he shares in this short, funny and inspirational talk, seniors are increasingly indulging their entrepreneurial instincts -- and seeing great success.

Check out more TED Talks: http://www.ted.com

The TED Talks channel features the best talks and performances from the TED Conference, where the world's leading thinkers and doers give the talk of their lives in 18 minutes (or less). Look for talks on Technology, Entertainment and Design -- plus science, business, global issues, the arts and more.

title: Empowering Women in Business & Management (long version)
description:
International Labour Organization
172K subscribers
SUBSCRIBE
Worldwide there is a growing recognition that more women in senior management and corporate governance makes good business sense. As a result there is increased demand for women in top management roles, for those who can start and successfully run their own businesses and a growing pool of talented women ready to take on the challenges.

But how can companies change their cultures and hierarchies to meet the demand? And how can employers' organizations best advise them to make it happen?
